content.description: A powerful start (harder for short people) gets you into a nice hand crack, followed by tight fingers to tip jamming and laybacking.  Watch out for the varnish, it's slick.
content.protection: .5 Camalot for the start, two .4 Camalots, three .3 Camalots, two green Aliens, one .2 Camalot.  Three bolt anchor

content.description:
This could be #13 in the book (2nd ed).

15' right-facing dihedral, finger crack that closes, do a couple moves of stemming and face holds (crux?) to gain a ledge system, then a curving, wide crack behind a flake gradually going to overhung (crux?) and the anchors.
content.location: Left of Aloha 200 feet, right of Slugs R Us

content.description: Climb two cracks to a ledge.  Squirm into a flared chimney and climb thin hands to another stance below an offwidth.  After climbing the offwidth, follow a thin hands crack that widens a little before the anchor.  Depending on hand size, you might find the crux to be either moving through the offwidth or the thin hands section after the offwidth.
content.protection:
Heavy on thin hands with at least three 2" cams recommended.  Varied other gear - doubles probably a good idea (down to 0.75").  Wide gear for offwidth, probably 5" is adequate.  Don't think I placed any 0.5 inch or smaller.

I don't think I was able to make it back down with a 70m, so consider two ropes or a 70m with bi-color middle marking (because I just might have used a 70m sucessfully - oh memory!).
content.location:
I don't know how you will have already arrived at the cliff (trail hard to find, if even present), but once you are at the cliff, travel along the base to the right (southeast).

Gain a ledge system by easy scrambling that accesses several established routes.  The first obvious route on the ledge is a short hand crack.  The next route over is this "unknown" route with no plaque and little guidebook info.

The route begins with a crack on the left face and a wider crack in a corner.  It then gains a ledge about 30 ft up which is just below an offwidth.  Continue up offwidth to left facing corner.   Anchors in corner below a roof.

content.description: Climb the crack negotiating a tricky move up higher right before a ledge.  From the ledge work up through worsening rock past small gear placements (crux) - hard to see from the ground.  Stemming may help, but whatever you do, the rock is not inspiring.  A few easy moves to the anchor remain.
content.protection: Bring a variety - probably doubles - but makes sure you bring a 4" piece.  Small gear is mandatory at the top (0.33", 0.4", maybe small nut).
content.location: As you traverse the wall right passing some routes and making your way towards the ledge area on the right side of the wall, you will encounter this route.  I believe there is a plaque.  Sorry for the vagueness, not sure if I recommend this anyway due to the sketchy finish up top.

content.description: Left facing corner that starts fingers and widens to 3.5", with all sizes in between.  Small roof at top.  The rock is good on this route, but it's hard to give it 3 stars, although for the Slug Wall alone it would be 3 stars.
content.protection: Fingers to big hands.  Bring 2 each of 3" and 3.5" (or roughly 3 blue camalots).  Anchor is so so - don't lower, rappel (of course this should generally go without saying for most routes at the Creek).
content.location: Towards the left side of the wall, but before you go left around the corner to the west facing routes on the front wall.  Obvious left facing corner on good rock that stops beneath larger roof.

climbs.name: Parting Gift
climbs.fa: FA - Nate Sydnor and Trevor Long  FFA - Herb Crimp February 27, 2021

content.description:
Joe Stern and I walked this wall a few years ago and saw this crack, noting to come back to it when the time was right. Well, this Spring I went through Moab and thought it fitting to try and organize the classic Nate Dogg crew manifestation, choosing this crag as the day's fare. I've always loved getting the gang together, and this was definitely an all-time group. Seeing as how I knew there weren't going to be too many more days when I could do this, I was so psyched to see it pan out.

Sam and Carl were there, along with the legendary duo of Charley Graham and Herb Crimp, and two of my other favorites; Joe, and the always-entertaining Trevor. We had PBRs and an awesome day.

The crack is a typical find that I like; thin fingers and bullet stone. I aided it pretty quickly, was relieved that the banana-shaped block was solid, and drilled the anchor. Being a little out of shape, I didn't even bother TR-ing it. I just kicked back and watched the crew go at it. Of course Herb flashed it on TR so I suggested that he lead it post haste, which he did, dispatching the FFA and rounding out the quick establishment of yet another classic.

I chose the name because this was one of my final days at Indian Creek for what may be some time. Giving this route to Herb was both a testament to our friendship, and an embodiment of all the qualities I love about climbing and the amazing friends I've gotten to share this pursuit with. Oh, and there's also a double entendre regarding the giant block just within reach at the start. ;)
content.protection: If I recall correctly it's blue TCUs, BD .3s and .4s, and maybe one piece bigger than that?
content.location: Just to the right of Pow Hana

climbs.name: No Ka Oi
climbs.fa: Jill Barr, Matt Laggis, Jill Barr

content.description:
Climb the twin cracks with good gear to the next section with very tricky to bad gear, this section is sporty and fun.

continue to a thin hands crack to anchor.
content.location:
Around the right side of the crag, on top of a ledge that must be scrambled to. Just to the right of the twin crack start 5.10+.

The twin cracks at the start of this route are much longer and straighter.

content.description: A tricky bombay start leads into a hands to fists right facing corner.  This will probably feel harder than 5.9 to most, but it is short.
content.protection: One each #1 & #4 Camalots, two each #2 & #3 Camalots.  Two bolt anchor.
content.location: Located about 50' right of Aloha on the same ledge system.

climbs.name: EZE aka EZ as your mother

content.description:
Don't know about yours, but my mom ran a half Ironman at age 53. Perhaps moms aren't so easy after all.

Long and varied, starts in a RFC with hands/fingers, passes a couple roofs, and finishes with a cool crack switch and splitter 4's. Leave the ground, scramble over some blocks, and quest towards the anchors up in the heavens.

A 70m got us down with only minor shenanigans.
content.protection: A selection of all sizes from .5-4 will see you through. Think I placed at least doubles of every size. An alpine draw or two would not go unused.
content.location: Approximately 50 yards right of the top of the trail, just before the cliff fully wraps around to the S Face. A plaque marks the start.

content.description: Finger to hands in a right facing corner.  The start is a little dirty but it gets better.
content.protection: .5 to #2 Camalots.  Chains at the anchor.
content.location: Hike around the right side of the wall passing several routes and scramble to the top of a rise next to the cliff.  Aloha should be to your left starting from a ledge.

content.description: Large, left-facing, black corner, tips to off-fingers
content.location: Left of Slugs R Us on the southeast face
